author: Meymo
body:
I did not downvote your comment, but I would add a couple of pointers: 

Typically, the people who are most vocal about impending doom are not investors. If someone is worried about a decline in their portfolio, it’s either because they are overextended, or they have no ability to generate new capital. If one is overextended, then any decline pushes the person closer to the edge with their investments. If one has no ability to generate new capital, then it’s more prudent to preserve what capital they have and not tie everything up in risk assets.

If you have the ability to generate new capital (typically through labor), then it rarely ever makes sense to liquidate all of your holdings and sit in cash. Instead, it’s much better to lean in to any decline and buy more. This discipline is what separates people though. It’s a very hard skill to learn (continued purchases throughout any market condition), but once one masters the skill, they will experience great things in their portfolio. 

While I agree with you that holding cash can be appropriate at certain times, being mostly in cash rarely makes sense. These posts (like the one OP created) are usually the result of someone who lacks the discipline (above) and missed out on gains and are now trying to conjure up an excuse as to why they think the market should go down, when the more relevant thing would be to simply buy on Monday, and then buy again the next time the OP has more free capital available. Repeat this buy step on a regular cadence and one day in the future the OP should end up with a much larger account then when he started.

author: therealsparticus
body:
**Tesla - Buy**

Currently a 10/11. Tesla has built the correct engineering team through survival of the fittest in order to compete to win. Tesla has Musk. Musk may be crazy but SpaceX is the first to build reusable rockets. Nasa and the Soviets didn’t even do the reusable part although to be fair, they were probably just focused on one-time to space. Musk is meeting that checkpoint and extending it. Andrej Karpathy is probably the best young AI application scientist. Great business/technical leadership - Musk, Andrej Karpathy.

**Square - Buy**

Currently a 7/11. Squares main revenue currently comes from point of sales technology which is highly saturation. It has shown the ability to pivot through a cash app and opening a bank charter. Fin tech has massive potential and Square is well positioned. Square is one of the places where engineers want to work for. Great business leadership - Jack Dorsey.

**Sea Limited - Buy**

Currently a 5/11. Sea Limited is competing very well in e-commerce, e-payments, and video games in South East Asia. These are probably the backbone of the economy of South East Asia as they don’t produce rockets or cpus there. This company is limited by the fact that it does not compete in the wealthiest countries in the world. Great leadership - Forrest Li, Tencent backing but not micromanagement on like competitor Lazada by Alibaba.

**Peloton - Buy**

Currently a 5/11. Peloton has potential to have the name brand “it” factor that wins in luxury goods. Some wealth people spend money on Gucci, some are frugal, but most are willing to spend something if they think it’s good for their health. This seems to be a product that looks like another fitness bike but somehow has a cult like following.

**Airbnb - Buy when IPO**

Currently a 8/11. In a world where wealth inequality rises, Airbnb provides a platform for travel housing for the rich with offerings for the middle class. In many cases, Airbnb provides a more authentic travel experience that money is trying it’s very hardest to buy. Airbnb is what timeshare could have been: myriad options, enjoyable to interface with as long as money is not an issue, and huge margins for landlords. Great business leadership - story of Airbnb founders is legendary.

**Draftkings - Hold**

Hype is too obvious and potentially too niche for valuation - however sports gambling is way less technically competitive in a field compared to CDN or AI and where deals and politics matter more. Draftkings is good at getting exclusive deals and has buddied up with ESPN. The fall back may be that middle class and poor people who want to gamble aren’t going to expand that much. The ones that have money to gamble are more sensible will not gamble and then ones that gamble against the house don’t have money. Most sports fans get enjoyment from watching the sports and hot takes by Skip Bayless. Wealthy sports fans have courtside seats and suites.

**Fastly - Hold**

Currently a 4/11. CDNs are essential but vulnerable to saturation. The competition skills is more technical than other tech companies. Fastly shows good signs because it’s CEO converted to CTO which shows that the company has a very technical voice at the top. Great technical leadership - Artur Bergman.

**Livongo/Teledoc** **- Sell**

It seems to be too early in the telemedicical market, and companies trade at huge multiples. Although these two companies are the leaders, their competitive advantage seems that medicine is a slow moving, heavily regulated field where winners will win more by showing up. Online medical services also seem very promising for mental illness which is big in America even among the wealthy, but teladoc merge dilutes this.

**Docusign - Sell**

The moment when Docusign becomes a full-fledged solution suite instead of feature, it becomes a huge buy.

**Rocket Companies - Sell**

Rocket companies are leading in technology adoption in the refinancing and mortgage industry. It is not clear that technology is the decisive factor.

**Okta - Sell**

Okta is by far the best single sign on solution. The valuation is already high and this seems more like a feature than full-fledge solution suite.

**Virgin Galactic - Sell**

SpaceX is too good to buy Virgin Galactic even though at this early in the stage, none, one or, both may succeed.

**Zoom - Sell**

Zoom is a great company with people willing to work 13-14 hour days for their potentially inflated stock. Issue is that their evaluation is already so high and doesn’t naturally grow into a huge field like Tesla may grow into energy industry.

**Slack - Sell**

Seems to be an expensive lesson for those who bought it. They are the best work chat tool, but work chat tool is not a feature and not a product.

>I feel the same way about my daughters. They are beautiful, bright young women. They are my happiness and my reason for living.

>Unfortunately they have forever tethered me to my wife and I don't have the heart to end our marriage because I don't want to hurt them. My wife and I have aged very differently. I've aged like a fine wine, she's aged like a banana in a backpack. I simply do not love her anymore and I wish I could go find someone else. author: prvncher
body:
They also charge developers $100 a year for access to those tools.
Application hosting is pennies, and in the case of Epic, the app is just a launcher with their CDNs feeding in the bulk of the data.

Charing a flat fee is one thing, but throwing a 30% cut without offering proportional value is the result of a monopoly.

author: buildyr
body:
If this borrowed money is a 1-time investment, then there are quite a few risks:

1. Stocks can go down and/or sideways for years. Look at what happened to Microsoft in the 2000s. From 2000 - 2010 it went sideways and down quite a bit. The only way to avoid that would have been to buy more shares on a regular cadence.
2. If the money is callable (e.g. tied to a margin account), then you run the risk of being liquidated at the worst time (see #1)
3. If the interest rate is over 4%, I wouldn't touch it. It's far too hard to "guarantee" returns beyond that on a YoY basis
4. Behavioral risks; if you dont have the means to pay on this borrowed money, you might panic and sell at the worst time (too many red days for your liking). This would result in you owing on a loan while also having lost value.

Now, all of these negative things aside, if you can borrow money for an extended period of time (e.g. 15-30 years) then your odds of success go up. In America, folks with homes are able to borrow money at under 3% (and in many cases at or under 2.5%). $100,000 spread over 30 years at 3% is only $422/month. If you can afford to take on that extra $422/mo payment (e.g. you have extra money each month and this payment will not impact you), then it may make sense to take on a loan since you've locked in such a low fixed rate. You could then put that money in the market and most likely (eventually?) earn more than $422/month. Over the next 30 years, many people have the expectation that the market will go up at some point.

Good luck.

author: silent_johnn
body:
> live just off of my positive return for the period, and the initial investment amount hasnt changed (since ETF's are 'safe'), thus leading to 'infinite money'

Huh? Do you understand how dividends work? Dividends are not free money.

Also how can you love off only $1,000? I'm no expert, but monthly is the highest cadence I've seen for distributions. 1k a month? Is that even possible to live off of?

author: Meymo
body: You can invest in companies which are both high growth and pay dividends at the same time. If your horizon is 20+ years, you should avoid items which solely exist for dividend yield. The most important thing you can do as an investor is to always be buying more securities. Buy on a regular cadence. Continue to put any extra money that you have into the market on both red and green weeks/months/years and you'll be all set 20 years from now.

author: curiouscat887
body:
Basically my strategy is to look at the earning calls for the week, on the day the companies earnings are announced I usually search for that ticker and see if there are any alerts.

Something with high volume and low IO that’s quite far out with a short expiry looks like a bet to me so I look into the company a bit more and then follow the bet. 

I know it’s not rock solid but these are gambles after all.

Most have made something like 20-30% within a few hours later. 

I missed the CRM one even tho I was going to do it, kicking myself for that, but with the ZM one I thought why not as it was 1.35 a contract.

Just wish I put 10k into it as I’d have 400k now and could retire on theta haha but hindsight is 20/20

author: nebuloushazybull
body:
For all you asking: “Wait, how tf did [insert CRWD, RKT, CLDR, etc] tank & ZM 🚀 to fucking 40%?”

And being like: “Fuck this market, this is rigged, it can’t be like that, etc.” 

Quit your bitching and process one thing and process it well. Read it 10-1000 times if you have to.

We’re in a fucking pandemic. Only the top dogs/upcoming and unfortunately overvalued as fuck monsters like ZM & CRM are gonna dominate and destroy agenda-related items like quarterly earnings. Their leaders and engineers don’t give a shit about how much their shares have gone up this past month or year. Even if they do; they care much more about making their products or services the only and most attractive offering in their domain.

Stop latching on to what you heard or what you think you may know of a company. If it’s not the top of its game or the leader in what it’s doing, even if new or old, assess against the current situation and play accordingly.

Yes ZM & CRM may not deserve the followed surges but hey, is anyone gonna need any less of either of these 2, especially during these times? Prolly not.

Cheers.

author: SnooRobots6193
body:
Just looking at some of the biggest top performers this year:

* AMZN PE Sept 2016: 192 (now 127)
* FB PE Sept 2016: 57 (now 34)
* CRM PE Sept 2016: 240 (now 99)
* NFLX PE Sept 2016: 310 (now 87)
* ABMD PE Sept 2016: 130 (now 80)
* DPZ PE Sept 2016: 41 (now 34; not a tech giant, but I bring it up cause it's among the most overlooked top performer of 2010s IMO).

And I didn't choose to compare with 2016 because it was some peak. The market climbed pretty much the entirety of 2017.

Obviously this list was handpicked and there are plenty of counterexamples, but the point is that growth companies have had growth priced in (and delivered on it) for many years.

body:
> Just a gut feeling but I think there going to be a decent amount of white collar layoffs coming. 

Oh yeah.

author: infinitelimits00
body:
So this is the theoretical explanation. Basically the IV increased so much to overwhelm any loss of delta, which is quite a big move in itself. So essentially a ton of people bought a ton of upside calls today could account for this massive IV increase. 

However, from a trading perspective this seems super exploitable. Essentially here's what it's implying. 

It's saying Yesterday there was an X % chance for Tesla to be > 800 (or pick any other upside strike) by September 18. Now Today, despite Tesla going down 4-5% at this current point, there is still an X % chance or even > X% chance for Tesla to be > 800 by September 18. That's insane!

Despite 1 day passing by and a 4-5% drop in stock, the probability, according to MM, didn't change or even increased at certain points in the day! And it's not like there's that many days until September 18 anyways.

I feel like this isn't a supply/demand issue. I think actually it's possible this market got broken due to outsized, black swan moves from stocks like CRM, ZM and DOCU who didn't even have an earnings yet that MM are so pressed to selling vol they jacked up everything arbitrarily across all names, which includes Tesla and CRM but should include others, which I haven't delved into.

author: infinitelimits00
body:
I don't think there would be many links talking about this but ZeroHedge did mention the call skew effect in tech in a recent article. I know it's ZeroHedge and they are permabears, but the data seems accurate. Essentially MM are so short calls right now that calls in some names cost 4x as much as puts the same strike away from spot. So a move like CRM or ZM to the upside makes the move like 5x larger. 

https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/apples-market-cap-surpasses-entire-russell-2000-due-option-insanity

author: OptionExpiration
body:
Since you worked at SIG, let's use the poker analogy. We know that retail has been buying calls across the board. We are short gamma and short so many calls. So we don't want to sell any more options at an x volatility. So retail keeps on buying at x+y and then x+y+z, etc. We keep on making sales at these 'inflated' prices and they keep on buying them.

I presume this phenomena is happening in AAPL. Got steamrolled in CRM (what a move) and ZM (today). So we keep on offering at higher and higher levels (and retail keeps on buying) which is nuts.

Because the big tech stocks make up a huge portion on the NDX (QQQ) and SPX (SPY), we can get a little hedge on buy bidding up calls in the NDX (QQQ) and SPX (SPY). Because we are bidding up calls, we are now impacting VIX.

This is the only explanation I have for you. I think you are probably OK selling a little vol here (but I would go smaller size because of this craziness... vol can still go higher).

author: OptionExpiration
body:
My feeling is that there is genuine panic at these market making firms because of these insane moves that just do not make sense (but they still continue because of the feedback loop). I would bet that a senior trader/partner has taken over these names (TSLA AAPL CRM FB GOOG etc) to make sure that the firm doesn't get clobbered too much.

We all know to respect the markets, but at some level the 'madness' has to end. Of course, nobody knows when that will happen. Notwithstanding, the 'edge' you get selling at x+y+z volatility is more than you got at x+y which is more than what you got at x. You may be wrong at the x and x+y levels, but at the x+y+z level you made up for your losses (from x and X+y) and then some. Thus, the snowball effect of implied volatility becoming actual volatility might be true at the x and x+y level and overstated at the x+y+z level. (There has to be some edge selling options because you need a balance sheet selling options versus buying options).

So I do agree with what you are saying that the implieds will eventually be overstating what is happening with actual volatility. Unfortunately, nobody knows what level this will be. Thus, selling vol in small pieces at higher and higher levels is probably the safest way of doing this (and this is probably what the market makers are doing). You should have enough edge that you can scratch a trade if it doesn't feel right...
